Title:
Palm foliage as pathways of pathogenic Botryosphaeriaceae
fungi and host of new Lasiodiplodia species from Mexico
Keywords:
global trade, cut greenery, invasive fungal species, new
diseases
Abstract:
Tropical palm foliage are increasingly imported to satisfy
the steady growing demand in European floristry. This palm foliage
presumably carries along diverse fungi whose taxonomic and functional
diversity have not been addressed so far. The present study investigated
Botryosphaeriaceae fungi associated with foliage of palm species
Chamaedorea elegans, C. metallica, C. seifrizii, Dypsis lutescens and
Lodoicea maldivica imported from Mexico. Six species were identified
using combined morphological characterisation and multilocus
phylogenetic analyses based on ITS, TEF-1Î±, TUB2 and RPB2. Besides
Endomelanconiopsis endophytica, Lasiodiplodia brasiliensis and L.
euphorbicola, three new species, namely L. lodoiceae sp. nov., L.
mexicanensis sp. nov. and L. palmicola are proposed. Apart from E.
endophytica mostly known as endophyte, L. brasiliensis and L.
euphorbicola are responsible for different rot diseases and dieback of
important tropical crop plants. In pathogenicity tests on apple and pear
fruits of temperate regions, all the six Botryosphaeriaceae species
induced necrotic lesions at different degree of severity, with highest
virulence of L. euphorbicola and L. mexicanensis on apple and of L.
mexicanensis on pear. The results indicate that tropical palm foliage
can be pathway of potentially pathogenic fungi that may give rise to
concerns with regard to plant health in the destination countries.
